history.content:
Because algorithms underpin literally every single computer science application there is. Without efficient algorithms, the software that makes 160 possible could not exist. The same goes for all the other courses you listed; they may be more practical, but all of them ultimately draw on techniques from CS 170.

------------

You get exposure to dynamic programming (tested heavily on interviews) and greedy algorithms (used in machine learning). You also learn the importance of parallelism and learn about heuristics (super important in AI). Linear programming also exposes you to some optimization, although only at a surface level.

Because algorithms underpin literally every single computer science application there is. Without efficient algorithms, the software that makes 160 possible could not exist. The same goes for all the other courses you listed; they may be more practical, but all of them ultimately draw on techniques from CS 170.

------------

You get exposure to dynamic programming (tested heavily on interviews) and greedy algorithms (used in machine learning). You also learn the importance of parallelism and learn about heuristics (super important in AI).

Because algorithms underpin literally every single computer science application there is. Without efficient algorithms, the software that makes 160 possible could not exist. The same goes for all the other courses you listed; they may be more practical, but all of them ultimately draw on techniques from CS 170.

children.subject: Do you still have the link? No offense intended, I would like to read what else these software engineers have to say.

I'm coming from anecdotal evidence, so I'm not morally correct in saying these things. I don't think many people would in fact try to post in public that "algorithms aren't useful for software engineering". In fact, a lot of data scientists do need algorithms and math knowledge. However, the fact that the OP mentions the other classes already means that he's asking more for specific applications rather than general mental training in CS. 

To be more clear, 

By algorithms I don't mean e.g. basic things like sorting/data structures. By algorithms I mean things like matrix computations/linear programming/graph algorithms/combinatorics, etc. If someone really did need to use algorithmic knowledge, then they'd probably need something specific/advanced that's not from CS 170 anyways.  

By software engineer I meant toward the vanilla software engineering side, e.g. Google/FB etc., not hedge funds or trading companies etc. A lot of anecdotal engineers from the vanilla SWE side (including so and so, IMO/IOI medalists) have said the most complicated theoretical code they've done has been a 3-line for loop, or almost none at all.

To be fair, a lot of software engineers have mentioned that the most complicated piece of algorithm they've used is "3-nested for loops"; sure, you can argue that "CS 170 helps for problem solving", etc. but I don't think the OP's question is wrong into asserting that "CS 170 is not that useful".

history.content:
I am not saying I think CS170 is not important. I purely don't have an idea of why. I am just new to CS. Never got interview or any job. 

To me, CS160, CS162, CS169, and maybe CS186 and CS189 seem way more practical and good to train myself for real world job (especially for software engineering stuffs). I didn't hate CS70 so I won't hate CS170. So little to no pain for me to take the course but just not a great joy. I am just thinking I may enjoy it more if I know why and how it is so important. 

Any general idea, any subjective comments will be appreciated.

Thanks
history.subject: Why is CS170 so important?
